content: Technology vs people: why some obvious mobility improvements take so much time to adapt to Evgeny Klochikhin Blocked Unblock Follow Following Apr 20 “If you build it, they will come” sounds great, but when it comes to mobility technology, things just don’t work that way. People don’t instantaneously adapt to new technologies, which can make predicting the long-term effects of new mobility initiatives quite difficult. New mobility technologies are not always automatically accepted by the public. AVs is another example to come. This becomes clear when we look at two examples: the rise of ridesharing apps and the impending development of autonomous vehicles (AVs). Tech for tech’s sake vs. driver culture The technology world is understandably excited about the prospect of autonomous vehicles. Yet a 2017 Pew study found just 44% of Americans saying they’d ride in an AV if given the chance. There’s also demographic enthusiasm gap, with higher rates of skepticism among women, respondents lacking a college education, and those over the age of 50. Yet even people who are willing to ride in an AV often have different ideas about how they want to use the technology as compared to Silicon Valley inventors. Proponents of AVs envision a future in which fleets of AVs circulate around the streets, enabling riders to hail rides on demand. If such a world were to come into fruition, we could significantly reduce congestion and carbon emissions. However, the public has to buy into this utopian scenario at the cost of (often radically) changing their current mobility habits. Take the concept of vehicle ownership, which is deeply ingrained into the American psyche–it directly clashes with the ubiquitous on-demand service model AV proponents envision. What’s more, wide-scale systems require wide-scale adoption. Even if we accept that AVs are coming en masse, cities will experience acute growing pains in the form of increased congestion, skyrocketing parking prices, and mismanaged curb space as AVs share the road with traditional vehicles without directly replacing them. Thus, the issue of equity is pressing: affluent demographics typically have access to high technology long before economically disadvantaged. In other words, the people who need AVs the most will likely remain priced out of the mobility boom for an uncomfortably long period of time. Anyone seeking to regulate the bad PR away through compulsory usage of such AV systems are facing an uphill battle. After all, people have historically clung to the systems which afford them the greatest agency over their lives. It’s no accident that the car is the symbol of American freedom, and a century of culture has been built around it. The associated habits, perceptions, and beliefs are sure to die hard, even (and maybe especially) in the face of shiny new tech. Top-down implementation of so-called “smart” mobility solutions is doomed to fail (or at least, to achieve success through unnecessary cost and frustration to all stakeholders). Instead, tech must work from the ground up, benefitting a critical mass of users through augmentation of their current mobility practices, rather than supplanting them. Even more laissez-faire approaches are unrealistic; human behavior simply isn’t going to change overnight simply because new technologies have developed. Ridesharing apps and patterns of mobility The recent example of ridesharing illustrates how people and technology can work in unexpected ways. Early on, Uber claimed that their service would reduce congestion because it is a ridesharing service. But that’s not how it’s worked out so far. Recently, Uber implemented a new rewards system . Users who opt for single-rider trips receive more points than those who have shared trips. This system encourages users to select single-rider trips, hence creating additional congestion. Evidence also suggests that ridesharing has reduced overall usage of public transportation . In San Francisco, bus ridership has decreased by 12.7% since Uber entered the market in 2010. This, of course, makes the congestion problem even worse. People don’t use ridesharing apps as a replacement for private car ownership, but as an alternative to public transportation. Ridehailing makes a few people happy at the expense of many others without access and resources. Now that ridesharing apps have been well-established, it’s clear that many of the early claims made by proponents were false. That’s because these claims failed to adequately account for human behavior. The Uber example has implications for the future of AVs. Despite advances in technology, most people still want to own their own car. Realistic plans for AVs’ entrance into the market should acknowledge this, rather than assume that people will adapt to any technology that’s presented to them. There will be a need for a robust incentive structure to encourage consumer buy-in to the system–incentives which don’t come at a cost to present solutions that most directly benefit the economically vulnerable. In order to do this, mobility systems must necessarily consider the mobility patterns people currently hold above all, so that they may cater directly to those challenges. This philosophy is counter to any approach chasing innovation in a vacuum. It therefore behooves city planners, car manufacturers, regulators, and tech moguls alike to remember where the rubber meets the road: in the daily habits of the average consumer, not technology wonks, influencers, and other early adopters. Anticipating AV’s traction among the former based on the response of the latter is asking for trouble. Instead, truly smart cities will realize that cultural change is always gradual, and that mobility is inextricably linked to culture. What’s more, the best-conceived technological solution can (and probably will) have unintended consequences, as ridesharing has so aptly demonstrated. New technology is never just about the tech. It’s also about people. Even as new mobility technologies come into society, people may be slower to adapt. Change is complex, and oftentimes unpredictable.
title_html: Technology vs people: why some obvious mobility improvements take so much time to adapt to
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Predict
Sign inGet started

Technology vs people: why some obvious mobility improvements take so much time to adapt to

Evgeny Klochikhin
Apr 20

“If you build it, they will come” sounds great, but when it comes to mobility technology, things just don’t work that way. People don’t instantaneously adapt to new technologies, which can make predicting the long-term effects of new mobility initiatives quite difficult.

This becomes clear when we look at two examples: the rise of ridesharing apps and the impending development of autonomous vehicles (AVs).

Tech for tech’s sake vs. driver culture

The technology world is understandably excited about the prospect of autonomous vehicles. Yet a 2017 Pew study found just 44% of Americans saying they’d ride in an AV if given the chance. There’s also demographic enthusiasm gap, with higher rates of skepticism among women, respondents lacking a college education, and those over the age of 50.

Yet even people who are willing to ride in an AV often have different ideas about how they want to use the technology as compared to Silicon Valley inventors. Proponents of AVs envision a future in which fleets of AVs circulate around the streets, enabling riders to hail rides on demand. If such a world were to come into fruition, we could significantly reduce congestion and carbon emissions.

However, the public has to buy into this utopian scenario at the cost of (often radically) changing their current mobility habits. Take the concept of vehicle ownership, which is deeply ingrained into the American psyche–it directly clashes with the ubiquitous on-demand service model AV proponents envision.

What’s more, wide-scale systems require wide-scale adoption. Even if we accept that AVs are coming en masse, cities will experience acute growing pains in the form of increased congestion, skyrocketing parking prices, and mismanaged curb space as AVs share the road with traditional vehicles without directly replacing them.

Thus, the issue of equity is pressing: affluent demographics typically have access to high technology long before economically disadvantaged. In other words, the people who need AVs the most will likely remain priced out of the mobility boom for an uncomfortably long period of time.

Anyone seeking to regulate the bad PR away through compulsory usage of such AV systems are facing an uphill battle. After all, people have historically clung to the systems which afford them the greatest agency over their lives. It’s no accident that the car is the symbol of American freedom, and a century of culture has been built around it. The associated habits, perceptions, and beliefs are sure to die hard, even (and maybe especially) in the face of shiny new tech.

Top-down implementation of so-called “smart” mobility solutions is doomed to fail (or at least, to achieve success through unnecessary cost and frustration to all stakeholders). Instead, tech must work from the ground up, benefitting a critical mass of users through augmentation of their current mobility practices, rather than supplanting them. Even more laissez-faire approaches are unrealistic; human behavior simply isn’t going to change overnight simply because new technologies have developed.

Ridesharing apps and patterns of mobility

The recent example of ridesharing illustrates how people and technology can work in unexpected ways. Early on, Uber claimed that their service would reduce congestion because it is a ridesharing service. But that’s not how it’s worked out so far.

Recently, Uber implemented a new rewards system. Users who opt for single-rider trips receive more points than those who have shared trips. This system encourages users to select single-rider trips, hence creating additional congestion.

Evidence also suggests that ridesharing has reduced overall usage of public transportation. In San Francisco, bus ridership has decreased by 12.7% since Uber entered the market in 2010. This, of course, makes the congestion problem even worse. People don’t use ridesharing apps as a replacement for private car ownership, but as an alternative to public transportation.

Now that ridesharing apps have been well-established, it’s clear that many of the early claims made by proponents were false. That’s because these claims failed to adequately account for human behavior.

The Uber example has implications for the future of AVs. Despite advances in technology, most people still want to own their own car. Realistic plans for AVs’ entrance into the market should acknowledge this, rather than assume that people will adapt to any technology that’s presented to them.

There will be a need for a robust incentive structure to encourage consumer buy-in to the system–incentives which don’t come at a cost to present solutions that most directly benefit the economically vulnerable. In order to do this, mobility systems must necessarily consider the mobility patterns people currently hold above all, so that they may cater directly to those challenges.

This philosophy is counter to any approach chasing innovation in a vacuum. It therefore behooves city planners, car manufacturers, regulators, and tech moguls alike to remember where the rubber meets the road: in the daily habits of the average consumer, not technology wonks, influencers, and other early adopters.

Anticipating AV’s traction among the former based on the response of the latter is asking for trouble. Instead, truly smart cities will realize that cultural change is always gradual, and that mobility is inextricably linked to culture. What’s more, the best-conceived technological solution can (and probably will) have unintended consequences, as ridesharing has so aptly demonstrated.

New technology is never just about the tech. It’s also about people. Even as new mobility technologies come into society, people may be slower to adapt. Change is complex, and oftentimes unpredictable.

  • Self Driving Cars
  • Transportation
  • Ridesharing
  • Uber
  • Mobility

  • Evgeny Klochikhin

    Evgeny Klochikhin, PhD is the CEO of Parkofon, a smart mobility company building a fully connected #MaaS platform. Innovation scholar, data scientist, engineer.

  • Predict

    where the future is written

title: Technology vs people: why some obvious mobility improvements take so much time to adapt to

New technology is never just about the tech. It’s also about people. Even as new mobility technologies come into society, people may be slower to adapt. Change is complex, and oftentimes unpredictable.
